Project Number: 53364-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
November 2019 
 
 
 
 
Papua New Guinea: Supporting State-Owned 
Enterprise Reforms

Policy.

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 28102019081920713470 Generated Date: 04-Nov-2019 7:31:08 AM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  strengthen  the  financial 
sustainability of state-owned enterprises (SOEs) in Papua New Guinea (PNG), helping to improve 
public service delivery. The TA will provide advisory support to improve the overarching policy 
and  legal  framework  for  SOE  governance.  It  will  also  support  reforms  to  strengthen  and 
restructure operations in specific SOEs. 
 
2.  The TA is consistent with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Strategy 2030 operational 
priority  of  strengthening  governance  and  institutional  capacity,  especially  in  small  island 
developing states, which face severe institutional capacity constraints.1 Under Strategy 2030, 
ADB will support SOE reforms in small island developing states to strengthen the quality of public 
service delivery, reduce the costs of doing business, and promote private-sector-led growth. The 
TA is also in line with the implementation priorities of the PNG country partnership strategy, under 
which  ADB’s  public  sector  management  assistance  will  include  support  for  SOE  reform, 
improvements in the business legal environment, and greater competition.2 The TA is in response 
to a direct request from the Government of PNG to support comprehensive reforms to its SOE 
portfolio.3 A  concept  paper  for  this  TA,  with  a  budget  of  $750,000  from  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6), was approved on 21 October 2019.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Key  challenges.  Most  essential  services—including  energy,  water  supply, 
telecommunications, ports, and air transport—are provided through SOEs. Kumul Consolidated 
Holdings (KCH) operates as the holding company for the government’s non-mineral, oil, and gas 
assets through the General Business Trust (GBT). The GBT owns the government’s shares in 
nine SOEs,5 listed investments,6 other assets,7 and major projects.8 KCH is the corporate trustee 
of the GBT and is responsible for managing the SOEs’ investments. 
 
4.  Available information indicates that SOEs consistently demonstrate poor operational and 
financial performance.9 SOEs under the GBT lost K129.9 million in 2018 and K62.3 million in 2017. 
The consolidated debt (commercial and concessional) of KCH and the nine SOEs was about K5.8 
billion as of 31 March 2019, subject to ongoing reconciliation. Given the important (and often 
monopolistic) role that the SOEs have in delivering key infrastructure services, their continued 
poor operational and financial performance results in expensive, inefficient, and low-quality 
service provision, and affects the competitiveness of the economy as a whole. The government 
is facing fiscal challenges, with limited scope to finance the restructuring of the SOEs. 
 
1  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
2  ADB. 2015. Country Partnership Strategy. Papua New Guinea, 2016–2020. Manila. 
3  The request was made through a letter from the Prime Minister of PNG addressed to the ADB country director for 
PNG, dated 24 July 2019. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 23 October 2019. 
5  These  are  Air  Niugini  Limited,  Motor  Vehicle  Insurance  Limited,  National  Development  Bank,  PNG  Ports 
Corporation Limited, PNG Power Limited, Post PNG Limited, Kumul Agriculture Limited, Kumul Telikom Holdings 
Limited, and Water PNG Limited. 
6  This is Bank of South Pacific Limited. 
7  These are PNG Dams, Kumul Technology Development Corporation, Government Stores, and Kumul Property. 
8  These are Port Moresby Port Redevelopment Precinct, Port Moresby Sewerage System Upgrade, and Energy 
Projects – Ramu 2. 
9  The data in this section is drawn from a briefing paper on an update of KCH’s performance provided by the minister 
for public enterprises to the National Executive Council on 10 July 2019.

2 
5.  Policy and legal framework. Weak legal and policy frameworks undermine commercial 
principles, leading to poor financial performance and service delivery. The Independent Public 
Business Corporation of Papua New Guinea (Kumul Consolidated Holdings) (Amendment) Act 
2015 provided the National Executive Council (NEC) with greater scope for direct oversight of 
SOEs, including powers to control board compositions of both KCH and majority-owned SOEs, 
authorize annual plans, and approve expenditure over K10 million. This has eroded the oversight 
of the SOEs and allowed political considerations to override commercial imperatives, resulting in 
a sharp decline in the financial performance of SOEs. Problems are exacerbated by the lack of 
timely reporting and disclosure. Most SOEs do not produce annual financial statements in a timely 
manner, and audited financial statements are not publicly available (including for KCH). Lack of 
transparency and disclosure further inhibits accountability. Boards and management in many 
SOEs lack appropriately qualified and experienced personnel, and corporate governance does 
not receive adequate emphasis. Women constitute less than 20% of SOE board members.10 
 
6.  Several policy initiatives have not progressed.11 While the government gazetted the 
Public–Private Partnership (PPP) Act 2014 in early 2018, it has not been made operational. The 
PPP Act provides an overarching framework for the systematic analysis of proposed infrastructure 
investments, including whether private capital is likely to deliver value for money. The limited 
number of PPPs that have been negotiated have been done on an ad hoc basis, with insufficient 
assessment of the costs and benefits, contract terms, and consideration of alternatives. The 
government has also not made its Community Service Obligation Policy (approved by the NEC in 
2012) operational. The policy provides a framework for identifying and financing noncommercial 
services by SOEs, rather than the current practice of opaque cross-subsidization. The Consumer 
and Competition Framework Review, undertaken in 2017, called for adherence of all SOEs to 
principles of competitive neutrality. The framework was endorsed by the NEC in 2018, and formed 
the basis for a draft competition policy. The policy is yet to be approved. 
 
7.  Sector-specific issues. Challenges for SOEs are also observed in particular sectors. The 
top three SOEs in terms of debt exposure are Kumul Telikom Holdings (KTH), with exposure of 
K1.44 billion; PNG Power, with exposure of K1.21 billion; and PNG Ports, with exposure of K1.10 
billion. KTH merged three telecommunications companies: bMobile, PNG Telikom, and DataCo. 
Although the merge is legally approved, the process of integration is ongoing. Moreover, bMobile 
and DataCo are technically insolvent. KTH has a mobile market share of about 10%, against a 
90% market share of Digicel. The Fiji-owned Amalgamated Telecom Holdings Limited (Vodafone) 
recently obtained a mobile license and is poised to enter the market. KTH estimates that, with 
critical solvency issues faced by bMobile, a cash injection of K100 million may be required in 2019. 
PNG Power works with several sole-sourced independent power producers, and commercially 
attractive opportunities have not been pursued. Financial management systems are improving 
but are still weak. Large unpaid power bills from government clients, together with political 
pressure not to increase tariffs, have made it difficult for PNG Power to reduce losses. Both the 
power and telecommunications subsectors lack adequate regulation. PNG Ports has privatized 
the operations of the ports of Port Moresby and Lae, the two largest in the country, but may also 
work to get private operators interested in some of the smaller ports. PNG Ports has substantial 
idle assets (e.g., land) which could be monetized as a source of cash to manage SOE liabilities. 
 
10  ADB. 2016. Finding Balance 2016. Benchmarking the Performance of State-Owned Enterprises in Island Countries. 
Manila. 
11 Assistance was provided by ADB through the Public Sector Development Initiative for these efforts. ADB. 2006. 
 
Technical Assistance for Private Sector Development Initiative. Manila; ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance for Private 
Sector Development Initiative, Phase II. Manila; ADB. 2013. Technical Assistance for Private Sector Development 
Initiative, Phase III. Manila; and ADB. 2015. Major Change in Regional Technical Assistance for Private Sector 
Development Initiative, Phase III. Manila.

3 
Air Niugini’s poor financial condition may have implications for plans to privatize Jacksons 
International Airport in Port Moresby. 
 
8.  In June 2019, a gazetted ministerial determination placed PNG Power and KTH under the 
minister of communications and energy and Air Niugini under the minister of transport. This will 
complicate reform efforts in these sectors, as it further blurs the lines between commercial and 
political decision-making. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  service  delivery  by  PNG’s  SOEs 
strengthened.12 The TA will have the following outcome: financial sustainability of PNG’s SOE 
portfolio improved. The outcome will be achieved through the following outputs. 13 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Advice on overarching policy and legal framework reforms provided. The 
TA will provide high-quality policy advice to government counterparts (primarily officials in the 
Ministry  of  Public  Enterprises),  which  can  be  incorporated  into  decision-making  on  the 
overarching policy and legal framework for corporate governance of SOEs. Policy advice will be 
provided based on demand as identified through policy dialogue between government officials 
and ADB staff, and will be prioritized to address significant gaps in corporate governance 
practices. It is expected that policy advice will cover topics including (i) separating political and 
commercial  decision-making  through  defining  the  roles  of  ministers,  SOE  boards,  and 
management; (ii) reviewing and clarifying the role of KCH (with capacity-building support as 
needed);  (iii)  improving  transparency  through  the  timely  preparation  and  public  release  of 
statements of corporate objectives, appropriate key performance indicators, annual operating 
plans, and audited annual accounts; (iv) clarifying procurement processes (in line with the 
National Procurement Act 2018);14 (v) implementing a transparent, skills-based process for SOE 
director selection and appointment (which would include particular measures to encourage 
women’s representation  at the  board  level);  (vi)  identifying  and  costing  community service 
obligations as part of the corporate planning process; (vii) addressing the backlog of accounts 
with  the  auditor  general;  (viii)  promoting  an  environment  for  greater  competition;  and  (ix) 
developing a framework for assessment of PPPs, including the costs and benefits, contract terms, 
and consideration of alternatives. 
 
11.  Advisory services provided through the TA can build the platform for reforms (including 
those  potentially  supported  by  ADB’s  policy-based  lending).  Gender  considerations  will  be 
incorporated into policy advice. Advisory services will build on work already undertaken with ADB 
support (para. 6), as applicable. Capacity building for SOE boards, management, and staff on 
corporate governance will be provided as requested. 
 
12.  Output 2: Advice on state-owned enterprise reforms in selected sectors provided. 
The TA will provide high-quality advice to specific SOEs in selected sectors on reforms that can 
help address their liabilities. This is expected to take the form of advice on specific transactions 
 
12  Defined by the TA. 
13  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
14  Government of Papua New Guinea. 2017. National Procurement Act 2018. Port Moresby.

4 
to improve cash flows (including through monetizing noncore assets owned by SOEs, full or partial 
privatization, and/or selling down shares), and on restructuring debt. SOEs to be supported will 
be determined in consultation with the government, and priority is expected to be given to SOEs 
with significant liabilities and to sectors where there is a greater need for development partner 
support. The TA will support the Ministry of Public Enterprises in outreach with other PNG 
stakeholders (e.g., Treasury, the attorney general, the NEC, and line ministries) to promote 
uptake of policy advice and recommendations, and also in managing changes under the reform 
process. 
 
13.  Advisory services provided under the TA will be closely coordinated with services provided 
under the proposed Private Sector Development Initiative (PSDI) (Phase IV) regional TA.15 Based 
on lessons from TA implementation in PNG, staff from the resident mission will be closely 
involved.16 Relevant TA outputs will be inputs into the k-Nexus to build on ADB’s accumulated 
knowledge and experience, minimize duplication, and facilitate dissemination. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $785,000 of which $750,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6). The government will provide counterpart 
support estimated at $35,000 in the form of making relevant country data available and providing 
counterpart  staff  (if  needed),  and  may  provide  other  in-kind  contributions.  Apart  from 
consultancies, funds for training events and workshops will be provided through the TA and 
administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. The TA budget may 
be increased during implementation subject to demand for the TA activities. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA over a 36-month period, from December 2019 to December 
2022. ADB’s Pacific Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants, and organize 
any workshops and training activities (in conjunction with the government). The implementation 
arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  December 2019–December 2022 
Executing agency  Ministry of Public Enterprises 
Implementing agency  Ministry of Public Enterprises 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB  
Individual consultant selection  32 person-months  $722,000 
Disbursement  The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, TA = technical assistance. 
Sources: Strategy, Policy and Review Department; approved TA concept paper; and ADB estimates. 
 
16.  Implementation will be harmonized with ADB’s other activities in PNG through close 
communication with resident mission staff. Particular attention will be paid to coordination with 
the PSDI to make sure that terms of reference (TOR), activities, and outputs of consultants 
 
15 ADB. 2019. Technical Assistance for Private Sector Development Initiative, Phase IV. Manila. 
16 ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to Papua New Guinea for Supporting Public Financial Management. Manila; and 
ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance to Papua New Guinea for Supporting Public Financial Management (Phase 2). 
Manila.

5 
engaged  under  the  two  parallel  TA  projects  are  consulted  and  shared,  including  through 
overlapping missions where needed. ADB’s objective is to provide the government with holistic 
assistance, with work under this TA and the PSDI TA complementing each other to meet PNG’s 
SOE reform priorities. Implementation of the TA will be undertaken in consultation with project 
officers in ADB’s Pacific Department working in specific sectors (like energy, water, and transport) 
where  SOE  reforms  are  needed.  Implementation  will  also  be  coordinated  with  other  ADB 
departments,  including  the  Private  Sector  Operations  Department  (on  telecommunications 
reforms) and the Office of Public–Private Partnerships (on PPP-related transactions). 
  
17.  ADB will also take into account TA provided by other bilateral and multilateral development 
partners,  and  their  operations,  through  regular  communication.  Key  partners  include  the 
governments of Australia, New Zealand, and the United States who are active, particularly in the 
power subsector; the International Monetary Fund, which expects to approve a staff monitoring 
program for PNG in 2019 with SOE reform as one of the pillars; and the World Bank, which is 
preparing  a  budget  support  program  anchored  on  fiscal  reforms.  While  no  cofinancing  is 
envisaged at this time, opportunities will be explored during TA implementation. 
 
18.  Consulting services. The TA will require a total of 32 person-months of individual 
consultants,  including  29  person-months  of  international  and  3  person-months  of  national 
consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants and carry out procurement following the 
ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and Procurement Regulations for 
ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). 
 
19.  The  TOR  for  national  and  international  individual  consultants  are  in  the  TOR  for 
consultants.17 The specific requirements for types of expertise and length of engagement will 
depend  on  the  scope  of  work,  which  will  be  determined  more  specifically  during  TA 
implementation in consultation with the government, taking into account evolving activities of other 
development partners and the government’s own prioritized SOE reform plan, which is under 
development.18 More comprehensive TOR will be developed accordingly, particular sectors and 
transactions to be supported will be identified, and deliverables from consultancy outputs will be 
further clarified. Consultants will be engaged on a continuous or intermittent basis, as necessary. 
Areas of expertise will include those needed to undertake SOE corporate governance reforms, 
support PPP and privatization transactions for selected SOEs, and provide legal and regulatory 
advice for required policy changes. Experienced experts will be recruited as lead consultants, with 
technical support from national consultants who have local knowledge. The recruitment process 
for consultants will commence early in 2020, after the TOR have been finalized with inputs from 
government counterparts. Consultants will be required to submit final reports to ADB and the 
government. Evaluation of their performance will be based on the findings of assessments by 
ADB and the government. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to 
Papua New Guinea for Supporting State-Owned Enterprise Reforms, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board. 
 
17 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
18 The Ministry of Public Enterprises has prepared a draft SOE reform matrix for 2020–2022, which is under internal 
government consultation.

Key Activities with Milestones 
 
1.  Advice on overarching policy and legal framework reforms provided 
1.1. Engage international and national consultants to support implementation of the TA, as per demand 
from PNG (March 2020–July 2022). 
1.2. Conduct periodic missions to PNG to work with the Ministry of Public Enterprises to prepare terms of 
reference, provide policy advice, and disseminate policy advisory briefs and/or reports (January 
2020–December 2022). 
1.3. Engage with the Ministry of Public Enterprises in outreach with other PNG stakeholders (e.g., Treasury, 
attorney general, National Executive Council, and SOEs) to build consensus and support uptake of 
policy recommendations (March 2020–December 2022).

Appendix 1  7 
2.  Advice on state-owned enterprise reforms in selected sectors provided 
2.1. Engage international and national consultants to support implementation of the TA, as per demand 
from PNG (July 2020–July 2022). 
2.2 Conduct periodic missions to PNG to work with the Ministry of Public Enterprises and relevant SOE 
staff to identify and support specific transactions in selected sectors (January 2020–December 2022). 
 
TA Management Activities 
Continue regular reporting and supervision until Q4 2022. 
Manage contracts from Q1 2020 until Q4 2022. 
Ensure the preparation of timely progress and financial reports until Q4 2022.
